@Laurarw60 @NicolaBellSP @FaithBorkowsky @londonjohn9 @KevinWheldall @RWheldall @speechwoman @buckingham_j @ReadingShanahan Exactly right Laura. I've seen this countless times. Through-the-word decoding makes kids proud precisely because they UNDERSTAND how whole enterprise works.

Memorizing and guessing is a fools game. It gives the ILLUSION of reading - an illusion that breaks down in 3rd grade.

b"@londonjohn9 @KevinWheldall @RWheldall @NicolaBellSP @speechwoman @buckingham_j @FaithBorkowsky @ReadingShanahan Books without pictures are fine. If the books have pictures, the teacher should not call attention to them with the intent of making possible the GUESSING of a word's identity.

This is not hard to understand John.

The more I listen to you, the more I worry."

NSW in Australia is going to adopt a phonics screening check for early readers. https://t.co/Tv0axqzaJy That's good news.

full_text:
I just checked in with @ncte, a group of supposedly professional English(!) teachers, to see if they are still supporting Whole Language.

Sure enough, they are - but now under the Orwellian name "Literacies for All."

I wish I were making this up.
 https://t.co/xTX6RmIluL

full_text:
Why not do both? Simple.

If you give a six-year-old both options, the easy guess-via-pictures route or the harder decoding route, that child will inevitably choose the easy "guessing" option. In no time at all, that guessing  becomes habitual.

Then what?
full_text(utf-8):

If you give a six-year-old both options, the easy guess-via-pictures route or the harder decoding route, that child will inevitably choose the easy "guessing" option. In no time at all, that guessing  becomes habitual.

Then what?'

full_text:
There's a distinct dividing line in reading instruction. On one side are teachers who encourage children to "Look at the picture" when stuck on a word.

On the other side are those who teach through-the-word decoding.

All scientific research supports the latter group.

full_text:
@londonjohn9 @MeehngunQwe @KevinWheldall @RWheldall @NicolaBellSP @speechwoman @buckingham_j @FaithBorkowsky @ReadingShanahan @SaraJPeden Only one - that's right. Now we're on the same page.

If you teach other strategies to a beginner, you risk having "looking for pictures" and "guessing" become habitual - and that's exactly how all poor readers read. 

Stop doing it John.

[And "yes" to your last question.]

full_text:
@MsMoore_Stanton Most irregular words are irregular only in their vowels, not their consonants. Even these can be "sounded out" especially if encountered in real text. 

Only a few outliers (ONE, COLONEL, for example) must actually be rote-memorized.

full_text:
Of course there's a

         THIRD (FOURTH) GRADE READING SLUMP

Many children were not taught to read in grades K-2. Instead, they were encouraged to memorize sight words, and to guess via pictures or context.

This gives the ILLUSION of reading. The illusion HAD to break down.

full_text:
Parents - The hallmarks of Balanced Literacy reading instruction are memorizing "sight words," guessing from pictures, and guessing from context.

These are red flags. If present, you need to take control quickly.

These books are FREE at the link in my profile. https://t.co/sR75PCrcRi

full_text:
***
                 "LOOK AT THE PICTURE"

This is the "go to" strategy for a reading teacher who doesn't know how to teach reading.

Children should be taught only one strategy for identifying an unknown word ---> DECODING.

Pictures can be used to verify, but NOT to identify.

Easy."

full_text:
@londonjohn9 @KevinWheldall @RWheldall @NicolaBellSP @speechwoman @buckingham_j @FaithBorkowsky @ReadingShanahan John, there are NO pictures in my free books for teaching a child to read. Only decodable words and then later, decodable sentences. 

In any books I read *to* a child, I of course discuss the pictures.

Pictures should never be used by a child to guess at words.

Easy.

full_text:
What is the "one great difference" referred to above?

It's simply this: What should you do when you come to a word you don't recognize: guess (via pictures, context) or decode?

All of reading science backs the 2nd choice.  (2/2)

full_text:
Reading Teachers - If you tell your students to "Look at the picture" when they're stuck on a word, consider the fact that no studies exist - none - that support that practice.

You're simply setting your kids up for the "third (fourth) grade slump".

full_text:
Reading Teachers - There has never been a study - not one - that has ever demonstrated the superiority of three-cueing as a method for teaching reading.

Conversely, there are hundreds of studies which have demonstrated the advantages of systematic phonics.

Teaching kids to read is easy unless...

You make them memorize lots of sight words.
You tell them to guess from pictures.
You tell them to guess from the context.
You tell them to guess from the first letter.
You consider yourself a "Balanced Literacy" teacher.

Reading Teachers - If you want your children to benefit from orthographic mapping, that is, from AUTOMATIC sight word creation, you need to teach them how to do through-the-word decoding.

Give them that skill, which involves BLENDING, and they'll be reading in no time at all.

@traci_SAReads I make no judgment at all on the question of whether "advanced," oral-only, phoneme manipulations skills such as deletion, substitution, and reversal help "at-risk" students.

I do object to the notion that ALL students need such skills if  OM is to occur.
full_text(utf-8): b'@traci_SAReads I make no judgment at all on the question of whether "advanced," oral-only, phoneme manipulations skills such as deletion, substitution, and reversal help "at-risk" students.\n\nI do object to the notion that ALL students need such skills if  OM is to occur.'

b'@lifelonglit I'm not trying to be "cool" Lyn. 

And I'm not disputing that such exercises may help kids who are in need of a specialist. 

What I am disputing is that such exercises are a requirement for all kids if orthographic mapping is to take place.'

full_text:
@OudersL Segmenting must be automatic for skilled SPELLING. Segmenting skill is not needed at all for reading.

Blending is the important skill for reading.
full_text(utf-8): b'@OudersL Segmenting must be automatic for skilled SPELLING. Segmenting skill is not needed at all for reading.\n\nBlending is the important skill for reading.'

full_text:
@traci_SAReads The only phoneme manipulations needed, for the vast majority of our children, are BLENDING phonemes (for reading) and SEGMENTING phonemes (for spelling).

I discourage other manipulations because they're a waste of time and because they're NOT needed for orthographic mapping.

Start reading tuition (Day 1) with some (continuant) letter-sound correspondences, and when 6 or 7 are mastered, immediately show how BLENDING works.

I'm just channeling David Share.

full_text: No, orthographic mapping is not a recent "discovery" (Kilpatrick, "Essentials," p99). It's a process that has been going on forever (if reading is taught correctly) but was recently given a new fancy name (by researcher Linnea Ehri).
full_text(utf-8): b'No, orthographic mapping is not a recent "discovery" (Kilpatrick, "Essentials," p99). It\'s a process that has been going on forever (if reading is taught correctly) but was recently given a new fancy name (by researcher Linnea Ehri).'

full_text: How can phonic decoding be what famed reading researcher David Share triumphantly calls the "sine qua non" of reading (https://t.co/p4ot0IsD1r), but what David Kilpatrick derisively calls "an old teaching method" (Essentials" p99)?
full_text(utf-8): b'How can phonic decoding be what famed reading researcher David Share triumphantly calls the "sine qua non" of reading (https://t.co/p4ot0IsD1r), but what David Kilpatrick derisively calls "an old teaching method" (Essentials" p99)?'

full_text: How can orthographic mapping, which has been going on forever, "require" training in advanced PA skills like deletion, substitution, and reversal (Kilpatrick "Essentials" p96) when these skills were unheard of before 2015 (when "Essentials" was published)?
full_text(utf-8): b'How can orthographic mapping, which has been going on forever, "require" training in advanced PA skills like deletion, substitution, and reversal (Kilpatrick "Essentials" p96) when these skills were unheard of before 2015 (when "Essentials" was published)?'

full_text:
To read (decode print into sound), a child needs to know how to blend.

To spell (encode sound into print), a child needs to know how to segment.

Teach these 2 PA skills well (with letters) and leave the "advanced" PA skills (deletion, substitution, reversal) on the shelf.

b'To read (decode print into sound), a child needs to know how to blend.

To spell (encode sound into print), a child needs to know how to segment.

Teach these 2 PA skills well (with letters) and leave the "advanced" PA skills (deletion, substitution, reversal) on the shelf.'

full_text:
To read (decode), a child needs to know how to blend.

To spell (encode), a child needs to know how to segment.

Teach these 2 PA skills well (with letters) and leave the "advanced" PA skills (deletion, substitution, reversal) on the shelf.
full_text(utf-8):
b'To read (decode), a child needs to know how to blend.

To spell (encode), a child needs to know how to segment.

Teach these 2 PA skills well (with letters) and leave the "advanced" PA skills (deletion, substitution, reversal) on the shelf.'

full_text:
@JoAnneGross1 @GettingWarm Spelling a word HELPS to reinforce the connections between the graphemes and phonemes of a particular word, but readers are reading, not spelling. Decoding new words through BLENDING is the primary way in which OM occurs.

This coincides with what David Share says as well.
full_text(utf-8): b'@JoAnneGross1 @GettingWarm Spelling a word HELPS to reinforce the connections between the graphemes and phonemes of a particular word, but readers are reading, not spelling. Decoding new words through BLENDING is the primary way in which OM occurs.\n\nThis coincides with what David Share says as well.'

full_text: @JoAnneGross1 @GettingWarm And this: "To build sight words in memory, OM is required. When readers see a new word, and say its pronunciation [by applying grapheme-phoneme correspondences and blending], its spelling becomes mapped onto its pronunciation and meaning."
full_text(utf-8): b'@JoAnneGross1 @GettingWarm And this: "To build sight words in memory, OM is required. When readers see a new word, and say its pronunciation [by applying grapheme-phoneme correspondences and blending], its spelling becomes mapped onto its pronunciation and meaning."'

Sounding out words accurately a few times is what enables orthographic mapping.

@ahmadalbeshri That English orthography is alphabetic (letters symbolize sounds), rather than pictorial (like Chinese or Japanese). 

If a language is alphabetic, one must teach children how the symbols work.

full_text:
What children need to be taught (explicitly, and at the very start of reading tuition) are letter-sound correspondences plus the skill of blending.

No memorization of sight words, no three-cueing, no guessing.

Teach this way, and most reading disabilities disappear.
full_text(utf-8):
b'What children need to be taught (explicitly, and at the very start of reading tuition) are letter-sound correspondences plus the skill of blending.

No memorization of sight words, no three-cueing, no guessing.

Teach this way, and most reading disabilities disappear.'

full_text:
Are advanced phonemic awareness exercises (deletion, substitution, reversal) needed for orthographic mapping (OM) to occur?

Of course not. Such exercises became a "thing" just recently. 

All competent readers over the age of 20 became competent readers without such exercises.

@debbiehepp Agreed. Phonics is not "baby stuff." It's how competent reading and spelling are taught no matter what the age of the learner.

And even skilled readers and spellers use phonics when faced with a novel word.

full_text:
@jennifer_2040 @TheAaveMaria Spelling is the encoding of speech into written symbols. The rules that govern that encoding are the letter-sound relationships that we call "phonics."

Without phonics, we'd have to memorize spellings like we memorize phone numbers - an impossible task.
full_text(utf-8): b'@jennifer_2040 @TheAaveMaria Spelling is the encoding of speech into written symbols. The rules that govern that encoding are the letter-sound relationships that we call "phonics."\n\nWithout phonics, we\'d have to memorize spellings like we memorize phone numbers - an impossible task.'

The only viable alternative to using pictures and context is DECODING. Through-the-word decoding, at the phonemic level, resulting in a full pronunciation, is the ONLY way to teach reading competently.

And it's the only way that leads to the automatic creation of sight words.

@dwofthepeople They're not the same. I'm not a fan of the rope. I think the bottom left category on the rope should be "decoding," not "word recognition." Under decoding: blending, knowledge of GPCs, segmenting.

The right category on the rope should be "reading comprehension."

full_text:
Reading Teachers

Here are four mistakes in teaching reading:

1) use of analytic phonics rather than synthetic phonics
2) "discovery" learning rather than explicit instruction
3) 3-cueing for unknown words rather than full decoding
4) requiring sight words    (1/2)

2) "discovery" learning rather than explicit instruction

4) requiring sight words    (1/2)'

Synthetic phonics teaches individual phonemes, with letters, from the start of instruction. Synthetic phonics is phonemic awareness on steroids. 

Then, as soon as the child is taught how to blend some phonemes, genuine reading can begin.

full_text:
Most children in Year 1 need no specialized phonological training (rhyming, alliteration, clapping out syllables, onset-rime separation) before starting reading instruction. 

Nor do they need phonemic training without letters. 

Not if synthetic phonics is used.

full_text:
This is not a small distinction. How a reading program begins greatly influences how a child will view reading.

Teachers, make your choice:

Balanced Literacy -> memorization & guessing
Synthetic Phonics -> logic & understanding
full_text(utf-8):
b'This is not a small distinction. How a reading program begins greatly influences how a child will view reading.

Teachers, make your choice:

Balanced Literacy -> memorization & guessing
Synthetic Phonics -> logic & understanding'

full_text:
Any reading program that starts with memorized whole words and guessing, and then later teaches some thru-the-word blending, is NOT, therefore, a synthetic phonics program.

Synthetic phonics STARTS with letter-sound relationships and blending.
full_text(utf-8): b'Any reading program that starts with memorized whole words and guessing, and then later teaches some thru-the-word blending, is NOT, therefore, a synthetic phonics program.\n\nSynthetic phonics STARTS with letter-sound relationships and blending.'

full_text:
I suspect many teachers who use onset-rime don't realize there are more than 400 rimes to memorize, just for one-syllable words.

Far less memorization is required using synthetic phonics - and it's far more effective. See my profile for FREE phonics books.
full_text(utf-8): b"I suspect many teachers who use onset-rime don't realize there are more than 400 rimes to memorize, just for one-syllable words.\n\nFar less memorization is required using synthetic phonics - and it's far more effective. See my profile for FREE phonics books."

full_text:
Onset-rime phonics is no better than whole word memorization. 

Take the word STITCH for example. The rime, ITCH, is in fact a whole word - one which must be memorized by the student.

And how is the student to pronounce ST?
STUH? STEH?

Teachers: There is a much better way.

b'@SarahGlaser9 I don't think the gateway to reading is spelling. A child can be taught to read without ever spelling a single word. 

The gateway to reading is knowledge of grapheme-phoneme correspondences and the skill of blending.

David Share calls this the "sine qua non" of reading,'

full_text:
@jeffrey_bowers For Year 1 students, synthetic phonics plus the teacher reading quality children's literature TO the class and conducting a discussion about that story.

This advances both decoding skills and language comp skills daily. The Simple View of Reading.
full_text(utf-8): b"@jeffrey_bowers For Year 1 students, synthetic phonics plus the teacher reading quality children's literature TO the class and conducting a discussion about that story.\n\nThis advances both decoding skills and language comp skills daily. The Simple View of Reading."

full_text:
@MsSelfExEd I understand how spelling is a (writing) skill that goes from speech to print. But reading is, in many ways, the opposite of spelling. (One involves encoding; the other decoding.) 

Reading MUST go from print to speech (sound). I'm still confused by the title of the book.

full_text: That‚Äôs because initially, sounding out words via blending takes effort. Guessing does not, and it‚Äôs easy. Kids are kids after all. 4/4
full_text(utf-8): b'That\xe2\x80\x99s because initially, sounding out words via blending takes effort. Guessing does not, and it\xe2\x80\x99s easy. Kids are kids after all. 4/4'

full_text: The reason? That which children learn first about reading has an outsized effect on their thinking about what reading is. In addition, if BOTH guessing at words, and sounding them out, are presented as options, children will always lean towards guessing. 3/4
full_text(utf-8): b'The reason? That which children learn first about reading has an outsized effect on their thinking about what reading is. In addition, if BOTH guessing at words, and sounding them out, are presented as options, children will always lean towards guessing. 3/4'

full_text: Some reading programs introduce these isolated sounds and blending LATER, that is, after having the child memorize sight words and use guessing strategies to identify words. Such programs are NOT synthetic phonics programs. 2/4
full_text(utf-8): b'Some reading programs introduce these isolated sounds and blending LATER, that is, after having the child memorize sight words and use guessing strategies to identify words. Such programs are NOT synthetic phonics programs. 2/4'

full_text:
Reading Teachers

Orthographic Mapping.

It requires no "advanced phonemic awareness."
It requires no segmenting skill.
It does require blending skill.
It does require letter-sound knowledge.
It requires thru-the-word decoding.
 https://t.co/w4rMul3pgy

full_text:
@Jansz06993032 Nice job Fiona.

Can you give me an example of words with UU, AE, and AO as digraphs?

Also, remember that to be a digraph, a vowel team can only represent a single phoneme.

E.g.  The UI in SUICIDE is not a digraph b/c U and I both represent a sound.
full_text(utf-8):
b'@Jansz06993032 Nice job Fiona.

In the 2nd syllable, the vowel sound is a schwa sound - at least in my accent. It's not pronounced LEN (rhymes with PEN), but rather LIN (rhymes with PIN).

full_text: The 2 key phoneme awareness skills to teach are blending (first and foremost), and then segmenting - both with letters from the very beginning.
full_text(utf-8): b'The 2 key phoneme awareness skills to teach are blending (first and foremost), and then segmenting - both with letters from the very beginning.'

full_text: And the notion that this "advanced" phoneme awareness is required for orthographic mapping to occur ("Essentials," p96) is far-fetched. OM has been going on for centuries without teachers and students engaging in such mental gymnastics.
full_text(utf-8): b'And the notion that this "advanced" phoneme awareness is required for orthographic mapping to occur ("Essentials," p96) is far-fetched. OM has been going on for centuries without teachers and students engaging in such mental gymnastics.'

full_text: Balanced Literacy relies upon ‚Äúdiscovery‚Äù learning ‚Äì synthetic phonics uses explicit teaching. BL ignores the Science of Reading ‚Äì synthetic phonics is the embodiment of that science.   [5/6]

full_text: Balanced Literacy does NOT respect the beginner‚Äôs need to understand how reading works ‚Äì synthetic phonics does. BL takes 4-5 years to cover the alphabetic code ‚Äì synthetic phonics takes a year or two.   [4/6]

full_text: Balanced Literacy does not respect the young child‚Äôs need to understand ‚Äì synthetic phonics does. BL takes 4-5 years to cover the alphabetic code ‚Äì synthetic phonics takes a year or two.   [4/5]

full_text(utf-8): b'Balanced Literacy (over)uses \xe2\x80\x9cdiscovery\xe2\x80\x9d learning \xe2\x80\x93 synthetic phonics uses explicit teaching. To learn more about the power of Synthetic Phonics, see here:   [5/5]\nhttps://t.co/bHmUXy6zp6'

full_text: Balanced Literacy does not respect that young learner‚Äôs need for logic and understanding ‚Äì synthetic phonics does. BL takes 4-5 years to cover the alphabetic code ‚Äì synthetic phonics takes a year or two.   [4/5]
full_text(utf-8): b'Balanced Literacy does not respect that young learner\xe2\x80\x99s need for logic and understanding \xe2\x80\x93 synthetic phonics does. BL takes 4-5 years to cover the alphabetic code \xe2\x80\x93 synthetic phonics takes a year or two.   [4/5]'

full_text: Synthetic phonics is always systematic and it‚Äôs NOT compatible with Balanced Literacy. Balanced Literacy uses sight words and guessing - synthetic phonics uses neither.  [3/5]
full_text(utf-8): b'Synthetic phonics is always systematic and it\xe2\x80\x99s NOT compatible with Balanced Literacy. Balanced Literacy uses sight words and guessing - synthetic phonics uses neither.  [3/5]'

full_text: The reason? ‚ÄúAnalytic‚Äù phonics can be systematic. Since analytic phonics is fully compatible with Balanced Literacy, a call for ‚Äúsystematic‚Äù phonics ends up being nothing more than a call for the status quo.   [2/5]
full_text(utf-8): b'The reason? \xe2\x80\x9cAnalytic\xe2\x80\x9d phonics can be systematic. Since analytic phonics is fully compatible with Balanced Literacy, a call for \xe2\x80\x9csystematic\xe2\x80\x9d phonics ends up being nothing more than a call for the status quo.   [2/5]'

full_text: I wish reading reformers would stop clamoring (as did the US National Reading Panel) for ‚Äúsystematic‚Äù phonics, and instead, call consistently for ‚Äúsynthetic‚Äù phonics (as did England‚Äôs national ‚ÄúRose Report‚Äù).  [1/5]

full_text:
This orthographic (spelling) mapping occurs automatically IF the written word SLEEP is correctly decoded a few times. 

Thus ‚Äùmapped,‚Äù SLEEP will never again be mis-spelled.
 
Synthetic Phonics ‚Äì it‚Äôs how reading (and spelling) is taught.
full_text(utf-8):
b'This orthographic (spelling) mapping occurs automatically IF the written word SLEEP is correctly decoded a few times. 

Thus \xe2\x80\x9dmapped,\xe2\x80\x9d SLEEP will never again be mis-spelled.
 
Synthetic Phonics \xe2\x80\x93 it\xe2\x80\x99s how reading (and spelling) is taught.'

full_text:
Good spelling is dependent on reading being taught correctly, that is, with Synthetic Phonics.

There‚Äôs no ‚Äúa priori‚Äù reason for the spelling SLEEP and not SLEAP. Therefore a child must ‚Äúmap‚Äù the correct spelling to the sound and the meaning already stored in his brain.
full_text(utf-8): b'Good spelling is dependent on reading being taught correctly, that is, with Synthetic Phonics.\n\nThere\xe2\x80\x99s no \xe2\x80\x9ca priori\xe2\x80\x9d reason for the spelling SLEEP and not SLEAP. Therefore a child must \xe2\x80\x9cmap\xe2\x80\x9d the correct spelling to the sound and the meaning already stored in his brain.'

full_text:
In other words, through-the-word decoding works as a self-teaching tool not only for regular words, but for most irregular words as well.

There's simply no need to compel beginning readers to learn sight words.
full_text(utf-8): b"In other words, through-the-word decoding works as a self-teaching tool not only for regular words, but for most irregular words as well.\n\nThere's simply no need to compel beginning readers to learn sight words."

full_text: "The hypothesis being proposed here is that most irregular words, when encountered in natural text, have sufficient letter-sound regularity (primarily consonantal) to permit selection of the correct target among a set of candidate pronunciations."  - David Share

full_text: @KatharineBeals @MiriamFein @SarahGlaser9 Homophones are also a bit problematic. 3-cueing goes against 40 years of scientific evidence that it doesn't work. This according to a new meta study on the Science of Reading (https://t.co/CUWD1tBXtp).

If you use 3-cueing, it's past time to educate yourself on alternatives.

1) Calkin‚Äôs Units of Study for Teaching Reading

5) instruction in reading comprehension
6) Reading Recovery

full_text:
A new meta-study on the Science of Reading.
A summary follows:

What theories and practices have compelling evidence?
1) the Simple View of Reading
2) explicit, systematic instruction in through-the-word decoding
3) phonemic awareness
4) alphabet knowledge

full_text:
Reading Teachers - For your children's sake, get past the fascination with "discovery" learning (example, the book "Words Their Way" by Donald Bear). 

Instead, teach your kids, explicitly and directly, how to read.

See here for why this is a necessity: https://t.co/QXeYP9qKhy

When you want to write that vehicle that travels on tracks, you don‚Äôt puzzle over TRANE versus TRAIN. You immediately know the correct spelling. 1/

full_text: It can happen when reading or when listening to another speak. Even skilled adults can decode or hear words they don‚Äôt understand. (Try reading an academic paper on Quantum Physics and you‚Äôll find yourself ‚Äúword calling‚Äù pretty damn often. /3
full_text(utf-8): b'It can happen when reading or when listening to another speak. Even skilled adults can decode or hear words they don\xe2\x80\x99t understand. (Try reading an academic paper on Quantum Physics and you\xe2\x80\x99ll find yourself \xe2\x80\x9cword calling\xe2\x80\x9d pretty damn often. /3'

full_text: These phrases are used by those who wish to demean Synthetic Phonics in favor of more meaning-based methods such as Whole Language or Balanced Literacy. Yet ‚Äúword calling‚Äù is nothing more than a comprehension problem. 2/
full_text(utf-8): b'These phrases are used by those who wish to demean Synthetic Phonics in favor of more meaning-based methods such as Whole Language or Balanced Literacy. Yet \xe2\x80\x9cword calling\xe2\x80\x9d is nothing more than a comprehension problem. 2/'

full_text: Reading Teachers - The situation where a child can decode words, that is, turn novel letter strings into accurate, full pronunciations, yet not comprehend those words, has often been derided as ‚Äúword calling,‚Äù or even more pejoratively, ‚Äúword barking.‚Äù 1/

I'm tired of hearing that "teaching reading is rocket science." Rocket Science requires 8 math courses beyond Calculus and a graduate degree in Physics.

Teaching reading is simple IF done correctly.

These FREE books can show you how. The download link is in my profile. https://t.co/i3Rphm35ig

full_text: @londonjohn9 @RurbsOz @buckingham_j @PamelaSnow2 @DTWillingham @ReadingShanahan @KevinWheldall @JohnKenny03 @mikesalter74 @NarelleLynch1 C'mon John. A non-sustainable consonant is a consonant who sound can't be sustained, like the sounds represented by the consonants D, T, P and others. This can be opposed to sustainable consonants like M, N, and S whose sounds can go on until the child runs out of breath.

@londonjohn9 @buckingham_j @PamelaSnow2 @DTWillingham @ReadingShanahan @KevinWheldall @JohnKenny03 @mikesalter74 @NarelleLynch1 How? Practice, leading to orthographic mapping.
If a child reads the words GOOD FOOD using the wrong OO sound in each word, the result will be unintelligible. The child learns by decoding first, and then analyzing if the result makes sense.

full_text:
@londonjohn9 @buckingham_j @mikesalter74 @JohnKenny03 @ReadingShanahan @DTWillingham @KevinWheldall John, in no synthetic phonics class could CAT be read as those other words you just mentioned. Only in a Balanced Literacy class could that happen.

A word becomes fluent and automatic through a process called orthographic mapping (OM). Synthetic phonics quickly leads to OM.

You're creating a poor reader.

@Dr_KOConnor Deconstructing words could help with synthesizing, but only if the deconstruction is down to the phonemic level - something that rarely happens. 

Synthesizing a word from the bottom up, however, makes segmenting it at a later date much easier. (3/3)
full_text(utf-8): b'@Dr_KOConnor Deconstructing words could help with synthesizing, but only if the deconstruction is down to the phonemic level - something that rarely happens. \n\nSynthesizing a word from the bottom up, however, makes segmenting it at a later date much easier. (3/3)'

full_text: @Dr_KOConnor I agree teachers are often stuck with a curriculum they would rather not use. I have no solution for that other than to directly teach the code as much as possible within the curricular constraints that exist.   (2/3)

full_text: On the other hand, synthetic phonics starts logically, without sight words, building from the ground up by blending phonemes into (whole) words. Teaching is explicit and children are never encouraged to guess.   <3>

full_text:
@RurbsOz In the US, the most common pronunciation of the word "a" is the short U sound (as in the word NUT). 
Interestingly, the pronunciation of THE also has the short U sound (along with a voiced TH sound).
full_text(utf-8): b'@RurbsOz In the US, the most common pronunciation of the word "a" is the short U sound (as in the word NUT). \nInterestingly, the pronunciation of THE also has the short U sound (along with a voiced TH sound).'

full_text: @RurbsOz P, of course, has only one sound. But when your daughter reads P words, we want her to articulate the initial P plus the following short vowel as a single pulse of sound. This habit will serve her well in the stages to come.

full_text: @_emilygreaves @PamelaSnow2 Hello Emily. Each syllable in those multi-syllable words should be doable for a child who's reached Stage 10. Reading Teachers ‚Äì Try this:

Teach phonemic awareness WITH letters, thus making it inseparable from phonics.

Teach kids how to ‚Äúsound out‚Äù unknown words.

Do this from the start of instruction.

Kids love it - and it works.

It‚Äôs called Synthetic Phonics.

full_text: @RurbsOz The word NO has a long O sound - something I don't cover in my books until stage 10. Stick with short O sounds for now.
full_text(utf-8): b"@RurbsOz The word NO has a long O sound - something I don't cover in my books until stage 10. Stick with short O sounds for now."

full_text: @RurbsOz After decoding a word successfully a couple of times, it automatically becomes a sight word for your child. The process is called orthographic mapping. You needn't worry about it - it's automatic. (I discuss it in the teacher's edition of my books.)
full_text(utf-8): b"@RurbsOz After decoding a word successfully a couple of times, it automatically becomes a sight word for your child. The process is called orthographic mapping. You needn't worry about it - it's automatic. (I discuss it in the teacher's edition of my books.)"

full_text: @RurbsOz Be careful of ADULT and APART. None of the A's in these 2 words have the short A sound. Instead, those initial A's have a short U sound. See "Lazy Vowel" in stage 13 for a more detailed explanation. (It happens in unstressed syllables.)
full_text(utf-8): b'@RurbsOz Be careful of ADULT and APART. None of the A\'s in these 2 words have the short A sound. Instead, those initial A\'s have a short U sound. See "Lazy Vowel" in stage 13 for a more detailed explanation. (It happens in unstressed syllables.)'

full_text: @maxcoltheart I'll hazard the guess that skilled readers have available to them BOTH modes of reading: direct spelling to meaning plus an indirect back-up path of spelling to sound (via GPC rules) to meaning.
full_text(utf-8): b"@maxcoltheart I'll hazard the guess that skilled readers have available to them BOTH modes of reading: direct spelling to meaning plus an indirect back-up path of spelling to sound (via GPC rules) to meaning."

full_text: @maxcoltheart I can't confidently answer your second question. It's an academic question and I am not a researcher.  Further, whatever the correct answer is, it does not affect how I think reading should be taught. When I read I can't suppress the sound track playing in my head.
full_text(utf-8): b"@maxcoltheart I can't confidently answer your second question. It's an academic question and I am not a researcher.  Further, whatever the correct answer is, it does not affect how I think reading should be taught. When I read I can't suppress the sound track playing in my head."

full_text: @maxcoltheart A skilled reader, by definition, would have a decoding score equal to 1, so reading comp would simply equal language comp. Therefore I think Gough and Tunmer would see their model as applying only to "learning to read."

1) knowledge of which letters symbolize which sounds
2) the ability to sound out (blend) an unknown written word into a full pronunciation
3) practice with decodable text

"Phonemic Awareness training is more effective when it's taught having children manipulate letters than when manipulation is limited to speech." (US Nat'l Reading Panel, p2-26)

Remember that the next time someone tells you PA training must be doable with eyes closed.
full_text(utf-8): b'"Phonemic Awareness training is more effective when it\'s taught having children manipulate letters than when manipulation is limited to speech." (US Nat\'l Reading Panel, p2-26)\n\nRemember that the next time someone tells you PA training must be doable with eyes closed.'

full_text:
Children can be made aware of phonemes in many ways, some more efficient than others. What's unacceptable is defining Phonemic Awareness (PA) however one pleases.

Example: PA, to be authentic, must be able to be done with eyes closed.

That's nonsense. Here's the US NRP: https://t.co/q4OyAW4GCU

full_text:
Is Phonemic Awareness (PA) something new in the past few decades? No. 

Is it authentic PA only if it can be done with eyes closed? Utter nonsense.

full_text:
Balanced Literacy Teachers - The problem with teaching beginning readers guessing strategies is that, even if you later teach them how to properly decode, they'll already have made a habit of word guessing - a habit they'll find difficult to impossible to break.

Why do it?
full_text(utf-8): b"Balanced Literacy Teachers - The problem with teaching beginning readers guessing strategies is that, even if you later teach them how to properly decode, they'll already have made a habit of word guessing - a habit they'll find difficult to impossible to break.\n\nWhy do it?"

full_text: @luqmanmichel @pwilton_ed @debbiehepp It's a simple answer here in the US: students are actively taught to guess. The problem here is how to get teachers to stop teaching that way.

full_text: @CroteauLaura @angelrabanas And by "properly" I mean Synthetic Phonics: teach grapheme-phoneme correspondences and blending from the start. This makes reading logical for children and it kick-starts orthographic mapping.    2/2
full_text(utf-8): b'@CroteauLaura @angelrabanas And by "properly" I mean Synthetic Phonics: teach grapheme-phoneme correspondences and blending from the start. This makes reading logical for children and it kick-starts orthographic mapping.    2/2'

full_text:
@CroteauLaura @angelrabanas Children can't simply pivot if and when they are taught how to fully decode. Guessing (via pictures, context, first letter) becomes habitual for them and orthographic mapping becomes impossible. 

The only remedy is to teach reading properly from the beginning.    1/2
full_text(utf-8): b"@CroteauLaura @angelrabanas Children can't simply pivot if and when they are taught how to fully decode. Guessing (via pictures, context, first letter) becomes habitual for them and orthographic mapping becomes impossible. \n\nThe only remedy is to teach reading properly from the beginning.    1/2"

full_text:
Reading teachers - consider this: perhaps the best way to teach a child phonemic awareness is to teach the actual phonemes DIRECTLY, right at the start of reading instruction.

Teach which letter symbolizes which sound and then show how to BLEND sounds into whole words.   1/2

full_text:
Teaching reading - it's certainly not rocket science. It doesn't require knowledge of morphemes. It doesn't require "advanced phonemic awareness."

It requires only some letter-sound knowledge and some "blending" (sounding out) ability. And it's fun to do.   /1

full_text(utf-8): b'RT @ParkerPhonics: Reading Teachers \xe2\x80\x93 Here are 5 signs that, during your teacher training, you were subjected to ideology rather than to re\xe2\x80\xa6'

full_text:
There‚Äôs a lot of confusion among reading teachers around the issues of reading comprehension and genuine decoding (fully sounding out an unknown word into a recognizable pronunciation). 

In this regard I find these quotes from researcher @maxcoltheart helpful: https://t.co/EDzwrSPI7V
full_text(utf-8): b'There\xe2\x80\x99s a lot of confusion among reading teachers around the issues of reading comprehension and genuine decoding (fully sounding out an unknown word into a recognizable pronunciation). \n\nIn this regard I find these quotes from researcher @maxcoltheart helpful: https://t.co/EDzwrSPI7V'

full_text:
You can begin to remedy ALL of these problems by reading my blogs here: https://t.co/8k27V7VbuY
and/or by downloading my FREE book for teachers, easily found at the link in my profile. (Forward by @Pamela and pictured below).   7/7 https://t.co/DrnDPR7yTJ

full_text: #5) You can‚Äôt explain the difference between the 4 types of phonics: analytic, analogy, onset-rime, and synthetic. These 4 types are NOT equally effective, and they are not all endorsed by reading science.   6/7
full_text(utf-8): b'#5) You can\xe2\x80\x99t explain the difference between the 4 types of phonics: analytic, analogy, onset-rime, and synthetic. These 4 types are NOT equally effective, and they are not all endorsed by reading science.   6/7'

full_text: #4) You do not have an adequate understanding of the Alphabetic Code. Spelling is based on that code. You can‚Äôt teach what you don‚Äôt know.   5/7

full_text: #3) You think that ‚Äúreading for meaning‚Äù must occur at the very start of reading instruction even though the child can‚Äôt yet decode any words. This betrays a lack of understand of the Simple View of Reading ‚Äì something accepted by reading science for over 30 years.     4/7
full_text(utf-8): b'#3) You think that \xe2\x80\x9creading for meaning\xe2\x80\x9d must occur at the very start of reading instruction even though the child can\xe2\x80\x99t yet decode any words. This betrays a lack of understand of the Simple View of Reading \xe2\x80\x93 something accepted by reading science for over 30 years.     4/7'

full_text: #2) You have your children consciously memorize lots of sight words. You have no true understanding of Orthographic Mapping, a phonics process that creates sight words automatically.    3/7

\xe2\x80\x9cCheck the first letter\xe2\x80\x9d

\xe2\x80\x9cChunk it\xe2\x80\x9d"

full_text:
If a word is not analyzed on the grapheme-phoneme level, it can't become an AUTOMATIC sight word.

Automatic sight word creation, via complete decoding on the grapheme-phoneme level, is called ORTHOGRAPHIC MAPPING.

It's not optional if the child is to become a skilled reader.
full_text(utf-8):
b"If a word is not analyzed on the grapheme-phoneme level, it can't become an AUTOMATIC sight word.

Automatic sight word creation, via complete decoding on the grapheme-phoneme level, is called ORTHOGRAPHIC MAPPING.

It's not optional if the child is to become a skilled reader."

full_text:
Further, even the child gets the word right, she has made zero progress toward remembering the word for the next time in shows up. 

Even worse, she is being conditioned to think of reading as "looking for pictures" and as guessing.

Who could think this is a good idea?

full_text:
What's the worst thing a reading teacher call tell a child who's struggling to identify a word?

"Look at the picture."

There are a million words in English. How many of them will have a picture to help with identification after second grade?

full_text: A child can read by "chunking" (as it's called in many Balanced Literacy programs) only if the child has gone through Linnea Ehri's 3rd stage of sight word development, which is word analysis on the grapheme-phoneme level. Chunking is the 4th and final level for Ehri.   /1

What makes a genuine Synthetic Phonics reading program?
1) the explicit teaching of letter-sound correspondences and blending plus

Item 1 without item 2 is not synthetic phonics.

full_text: By "reading the word" I mean assigning an appropriate sound (phoneme) to each of the unknown word's letters (graphemes), and then BLENDING those sounds, left to right, to form a complete pronunciation. Another name for this is "sounding the word out."
full_text(utf-8): b'By "reading the word" I mean assigning an appropriate sound (phoneme) to each of the unknown word\'s letters (graphemes), and then BLENDING those sounds, left to right, to form a complete pronunciation. Another name for this is "sounding the word out."'

full_text: Balanced Literacy encourages many techniques for identifying an unknown word - every technique imaginable except actually reading the word.
full_text(utf-8): b'Balanced Literacy encourages many techniques for identifying an unknown word - every technique imaginable except actually reading the word.'

full_text: Synthetic phonics does NOT rely on sight words and guessing. Instead, instruction starts with single letters and the sounds (phonemes) those letters symbolize. Then, faced with an unknown word, the child is taught to BLEND all the sounds...  /5

full_text: Both analytic and analogy phonics rely heavily on guessing the identity of unknown words by using pictures, context, or the word‚Äôs first letter ‚Äì an awful habit that haunts students for years and hurts their chances at ever becoming proficient readers. /4

full_text: Analogy phonics (e.g. Onset-Rime) needs something to analogize from; hence the need, again, for sight words. Most teachers who use this type of phonics don‚Äôt realize there are over 400 rimes just for one-syllable words. Used extensively in Balanced Literacy. /3
full_text(utf-8): b'Analogy phonics (e.g. Onset-Rime) needs something to analogize from; hence the need, again, for sight words. Most teachers who use this type of phonics don\xe2\x80\x99t realize there are over 400 rimes just for one-syllable words. Used extensively in Balanced Literacy. /3'

full_text: Analytic phonics needs words to analyze; hence the need for a large cache of rote-memorized sight words just to get started. Then, add 3-5 additional years for kids to ‚Äúdiscover‚Äù the alphabetic code. It‚Äôs perfectly suited to ‚ÄúBalanced‚Äù Literacy.  /2

Reading Teachers - Did you know that sight words come in two flavors?

1) CONSCIOUS memorization of the word based on its visual features (hard for kids, or anyone else, to do)
2) UNCONSCIOUS creation of sight words due to an automatic process called Orthographic Mapping.

full_text:
"Teaching Reading Really is Rocket Science."

Nonsense. I don't know where this notion comes from but it's not helpful.

I can teach a child to read by giving that child 2 skills: knowledge of letter-sound correspondences and the skill of BLENDING. It takes about a year.   /1

a word that will never again need to be sounded out. This is the only possible way a child can create the 60,000 sight words needed for success in college.

This process is called "orthographic mapping."

It's not optional for becoming a skilled reader.

full_text: Only by DECODING an unknown word, that is, by BLENDING ALL the sounds suggested by the word's spelling into a complete pronunciation, can a sight word be created automatically. Only 2-5 such successful decodings are needed for the word to become a sight word, (continued)

full_text: Reading Teachers - Teaching a child to guess when faced with an unknown word, using the picture or the context of the sentence, is counterproductive because, even if the child guesses correctly, the child makes no progress in converting that word automatically into a sight word.

full_text:
We won‚Äôt ‚Äúlie‚Äù by telling kids that 3 follows 2. No way! We‚Äôll show them immediately how there are an INFINITE number of numbers between 2 and 3. 

We‚Äôll demonstrate right away how the concept of ‚Äúplace value‚Äù can enrich their understanding of multi-digit numbers. /4

Teaching a child to read is NOT "rocket science".

Simply teach which sounds go with which letters (the simplest first) and then teach the child how to BLEND the sounds suggested by an unknown word's spelling.

That's it.

A synthetic phonics program MUST start with grapheme-phoneme correspondences and blending - thereby demonstrating to the child - right from the beginning - that reading is a logical activity.

Any other start is sub-optimal and will derail many children.
full_text(utf-8): b'A synthetic phonics program MUST start with grapheme-phoneme correspondences and blending - thereby demonstrating to the child - right from the beginning - that reading is a logical activity.\n\nAny other start is sub-optimal and will derail many children.'

full_text:
It is NOT a Synthetic Phonics program if reading instruction starts with memorized sight words and guessing from pictures.

And this remains true even if letter-sound relationships and blending instruction do take place later in the program.
full_text(utf-8): b'It is NOT a Synthetic Phonics program if reading instruction starts with memorized sight words and guessing from pictures.\n\nAnd this remains true even if letter-sound relationships and blending instruction do take place later in the program.'

I wonder: have these folks ever actually taught a 5-yr-old?

full_text:
By ‚Äúfull decoding‚Äù I mean:
 
1) assigning the proper sound (phoneme) to each letter (or letter pair) seen in the word (this requires direct, explicit teaching)

AND

2) blending those sounds, in order, from left to right, to form a complete pronunciation 3/5
full_text(utf-8):
b'By \xe2\x80\x9cfull decoding\xe2\x80\x9d I mean:
 
1) assigning the proper sound (phoneme) to each letter (or letter pair) seen in the word (this requires direct, explicit teaching)

AND

2) blending those sounds, in order, from left to right, to form a complete pronunciation 3/5'

full_text:
Orthographic Mapping (OM), which is just another name for ‚Äúautomatic sight word creation,‚Äù requires ‚Äúfull decoding.‚Äù

Without OM, a child will never achieve the 60,000 sight words necessary for college success. 2/5

full_text:
Reading Teachers - the 2 worst things you can say to a beginner faced with reading an unknown word are:

1) Look at the picture.
2) What would make sense?

Why? It takes the child‚Äôs focus off the exact sequence of letters and thus keeps Orthographic Mapping from occurring. 1/5

Synthetic Phonics does (by design).

OM is necessary for the child to become a skilled reader.

Sight words are the bane of all early years' readers. 
Rote memorization of such words is difficult grunt work that gives the child an entirely false view of what reading is.

full_text(utf-8):
b"Sight words are the bane of all early years' readers. 
Rote memorization of such words is difficult grunt work that gives the child an entirely false view of what reading is.

Don't do it! It can easily be avoided. See here:
https://t.co/w4rMul3pgy"

** READING the unknown word by sounding it out **

Every time I write about 3-cueing, my spell-checker flags the word "cueing."

I refuse to add the word to my computer's dictionary for a simple reason: just as it's not a valid word, it's not a valid teaching technique. It should never be used on young readers.

full_text:
What constitutes the Education Establishment?

- @NCTE (still supports Whole Language!)
- @ILAToday (where's the leadership?)
- many professors in Education Departments and teacher prep programs world-wide

Here are two warning signs:

1) Your child is continually bringing home lists of "sight words" to be memorized. (No child should have to put up with this!)

2) Your child seems to rely on pictures rather than on the letters of unknown words. (Try hiding the pictures.)

full_text:
@katiebillington @TRT_Tricia @lisa_jeffery1 @BDAdyslexia @debbiehepp @SWLiteracy LOOSE is phonetically regular (MOOSE, GOOSE):
/l/ + /ew/ + /s/
LOSE is irregular (ought to rhyme with CLOSE and POSE):
/l/ + /ew/ + /z/ (instead, rhymes with BOOZE)
The only difference is in the final phoneme.

For more information, see here:
https://t.co/7GwYm3Cu3r
full_text(utf-8):
b'@katiebillington @TRT_Tricia @lisa_jeffery1 @BDAdyslexia @debbiehepp @SWLiteracy LOOSE is phonetically regular (MOOSE, GOOSE):

LOSE is irregular (ought to rhyme with CLOSE and POSE):
/l/ + /ew/ + /z/ (instead, rhymes with BOOZE)
The only difference is in the final phoneme.

full_text: @AnnieMaryUnger But the alternative to BL (a top-down approach) is Synthetic Phonics (the only bottom-up approach). See here: https://t.co/fr0ndoicnU. It looks to me like Structured Literacy only complicates what is a straight-forward process: teaching a child to read.
full_text(utf-8): b'@AnnieMaryUnger But the alternative to BL (a top-down approach) is Synthetic Phonics (the only bottom-up approach). See here: https://t.co/fr0ndoicnU. It looks to me like Structured Literacy only complicates what is a straight-forward process: teaching a child to read.'

full_text: @Phonics_Psych @ErinSchryer Synthetic Phonics is never phonics alone. In the 2 years (max) it takes to do it, language comprehension is also advanced by the teacher reading quality literature to the class (and discussing it with them). It's the Simple View of Reading.
full_text(utf-8): b"@Phonics_Psych @ErinSchryer Synthetic Phonics is never phonics alone. In the 2 years (max) it takes to do it, language comprehension is also advanced by the teacher reading quality literature to the class (and discussing it with them). It's the Simple View of Reading."

full_text: @Phonics_Psych @ErinSchryer "Can and should?" Why? Why not throw in etymology as well? Answer: Because they're five and six year olds. Stick to the main task: showing them how to convert those squiggly marks on the page into sound they can comprehend. Once they can do that, start with the rest.

It can't all be done concurrently.

full_text:
@EminaMcLean Fluency is the result of orthographic mapping - OM happens most efficiently under Synthetic Phonics. SP, by the way, is phonemic awareness on steroids - the exact PA needed to kick start OM. 

I'm still not seeing the need for a new name like Structured Literacy.
full_text(utf-8): b"@EminaMcLean Fluency is the result of orthographic mapping - OM happens most efficiently under Synthetic Phonics. SP, by the way, is phonemic awareness on steroids - the exact PA needed to kick start OM. \n\nI'm still not seeing the need for a new name like Structured Literacy."

full_text: @ErinSchryer But SP is NOT just one of the five. It's phonemic awareness on steroids - the exact type of PA that leads to orthographic mapping. Done correctly, SP leads to fluency (via OM) and comprehension (via the Simple View).
full_text(utf-8): b"@ErinSchryer But SP is NOT just one of the five. It's phonemic awareness on steroids - the exact type of PA that leads to orthographic mapping. Done correctly, SP leads to fluency (via OM) and comprehension (via the Simple View)."

full_text: @WritingKendra Also, SP is eminently based on reading science. You're telling me similarities, not differences.
full_text(utf-8): b"@WritingKendra Also, SP is eminently based on reading science. You're telling me similarities, not differences."

full_text:
@WritingKendra Who associates SP with intervention and/or small group work? I don't. SP is a stand-alone method for teaching a child to read - and it's best done as whole-class instruction.

I'm curious to know how Structured Lit is different from competent SP instruction.

full_text:
Should Donald Bear's book "Words Their Way" be used to teach reading? The phonics in it is indeed systematic, and there are lots of fun sorting games for children to do as they "discover" the alphabetic code. 

I don't think it should be used for two reasons...

full_text: @LearnerLit Yes, it's valid - once the child can fully decode unknown words into a complete pronunciation.
full_text(utf-8): b"@LearnerLit Yes, it's valid - once the child can fully decode unknown words into a complete pronunciation."

full_text: A child must first be taught, explicitly (because "discovery" learning takes too long), how to convert those squiggly marks on paper into sound. After that, they'll be plenty of time (in fact, a lifetime) to worry about meaning and comprehension.
full_text(utf-8): b'A child must first be taught, explicitly (because "discovery" learning takes too long), how to convert those squiggly marks on paper into sound. After that, they\'ll be plenty of time (in fact, a lifetime) to worry about meaning and comprehension.'

full_text:
Even limited to 280 characters, I can state all that's necessary to teach a child to read:

1) knowledge of which letter(s) symbolizes which sound(s)
2) the ability to sound out (blend) an unknown written word into a full pronunciation
3) practice with decodable text

/Q.E.D. https://t.co/csvBVQiall

full_text: @Fams4HG Dealing with word parts does not lead to orthographic mapping (OM). For OM to happen, a word must be analyzed on the grapheme-phoneme level a few times. Then it becomes a sight word automatically. A fuller explanation is on my blog. https://t.co/8k27V7VbuY

full_text:
@EmilyAmieWitty There's nothing wrong with children's books having pictures. 

The problem arises when those pictures are used by the child to guess what an unknown word might be. Unknown words should be decoded: the sounds of ALL its letters should be blended, L to R, to form a pronunciation.
full_text(utf-8): b"@EmilyAmieWitty There's nothing wrong with children's books having pictures. \n\nThe problem arises when those pictures are used by the child to guess what an unknown word might be. Unknown words should be decoded: the sounds of ALL its letters should be blended, L to R, to form a pronunciation."

full_text:
How did "look at the picture" ever become a "thing" in reading instruction?

There are a million words in English. How many of them will have a picture to help with identification after second grade?

No reading teacher should ever tell a child to "look at the picture."

full_text:
There are many unhelpful ways for a beginner to identify an unknown written word: 

- compare it to a memorized sight word
- ask someone what it is
- guess what it might be based on a picture, context, or the word's 1st letter.

But the best way is to READ it.

b"There are many unhelpful ways for a beginner to identify an unknown written word: 

- compare it to a memorized sight word
- ask someone what it is
- guess what it might be based on a picture, context, or the word's 1st letter.

But the best way is to READ it."

full_text: @NarelleLynch1 I'll say this Narelle: No beginning reading teacher should have 30 students. That's an impossible task. On top of that, teachers are then told to "differentiate instruction" for each of those students and to match teaching to individual "learning styles." That\'s just a fantasy.'

full_text: @NarelleLynch1 Those various processes are not "symbiotic." Three-cueing takes the student's attention away from the one thing that is important: decoding the word into a full pronunciation in order to map that spelling onto long-term memory.
full_text(utf-8): b'@NarelleLynch1 Those various processes are not "symbiotic." Three-cueing takes the student\'s attention away from the one thing that is important: decoding the word into a full pronunciation in order to map that spelling onto long-term memory.'

full_text:
@NarelleLynch1 Any synthetic phonics student, properly trained, could easily read HOME, in or out of context, properly, with a long O. Three-cueing has no basis in the science of reading. I do wish you'd stop supporting it.

PS. Many of us have classroom experience besides yourself.

full_text:
There are many ways for a beginner to identify an unknown written word: 

compare it to a memorized word, ask someone what it is, or guess what it might be based on a picture, context, or the word's 1st letter.

But the best way is to READ it. Everything else is a waste of time.

Progress only comes from "orthographic mapping."

full_text:
How could "Look at the picture" ever have become a "thing" in reading instruction? 

There are over a million words in English. How many of them will have a picture to help with identification after, say, third grade?

No reading teacher should ever say "Look at the picture."

@dzyngier @NickieSimonetti @NarelleLynch1 Not interested in "gotcha" games David. For most teachers, decoding is dead last in priority among the 3 cues - and even then, what those teachers mean by "decoding" is looking at only the first (and perhaps, last) letter of the unknown word. 

That's folly.

full_text: @NickieSimonetti @NarelleLynch1 @dzyngier Nickie, I have no problem with context being used in a "supportive" role to decoding - as long as decoding is primary. Cueing systems always place decoding last. Even if a child correctly guesses a word's meaning using context, no progress is made in orthographic mapping.

Cueing systems always place decoding last. Even if a child correctly guesses a word\'s meaning using context, no progress is made in orthographic mapping.'

full_text:
Reading Teachers and Parents - The alphabet consists of 26 characters, all of which are symbols for sound. 

Teach that alphabetic code systematically from the get-go, along with blending, and children will be reading in no time.

These books are FREE at the link in my profile. https://t.co/YBFx6x7rDJ

full_text:
Synthetic Phonics starts with the code rather than with memorized sight words. Faced with an unknown word, a child is taught to blend the sounds of the word's letters into a pronunciation.

The only phoneme awareness a child needs to read is blending and segmenting - both using letters.

Notation like CVC, CVCC, and CVCe are often encountered in phonics books. It's important not to confuse vowel letters (of which there are 5) and vowel sounds (of which there are about 20). 

See here for a discussion by @debbiehepp 
https://t.co/VJKV6aaTbk

full_text:
It's easy to produce unwanted behavior in a child:

Give him a goal he knows he MUST reach, like "learn how to read."

Make the goal unattainable by providing him with poor instruction.

Assure this assault on his self-worth happens EVERY day.

Provide him with no escape route. https://t.co/Mzt8YjVQ0E

b"@NarelleLynch1 @ReadingShanahan I'm with you on this Narelle. BEACH is a CVC word - a vowel phoneme between 2 consonant phonemes - 3 phonemes total.

I use CVC consistently this way throughout my book for teachers. 

The alternative? SHUSH would be a CCVCC word (like STAMP)."

full_text:
@FaithBorkowsky Most research, that is, most non-McGuinness research, is neutral on this issue of early names - or it finds that early letter names is actually helpful to learning sounds. 

See Seidenberg (pp 107-109) if you have it handy (as just one example). I have many more.

I have many more.'

full_text:
It you're a reading reformer, it's futile to call for "explicit, systematic phonics." The US NRP called for that 20 years ago. The result? Whole Language simply morphed into Balanced Literacy by adding on some Analytic and/or Analogy Phonics. 

See here: https://t.co/bHmUXy6zp6

full_text: @SarahGlaser9 @CherylCrocket11 Precisely--Onset and rime works as the final stage of Synthetic Phonics decoding. But Balanced Literacy fans want to use it at the beginning with memorized sight words. They hope to avoid the hassle of through-the-word decoding. It doesn't work.
full_text(utf-8): b"@SarahGlaser9 @CherylCrocket11 Precisely--Onset and rime works as the final stage of Synthetic Phonics decoding. But Balanced Literacy fans want to use it at the beginning with memorized sight words. They hope to avoid the hassle of through-the-word decoding. It doesn't work."

full_text:
@SarahGlaser9 @CherylCrocket11 But if LIKE is memorized as a sight word from the beginning (as is often the case in BL) then it can't be successfully used to read BIKE and HIKE. 

Let me know if u want a reference to her article.
full_text(utf-8): b"@SarahGlaser9 @CherylCrocket11 But if LIKE is memorized as a sight word from the beginning (as is often the case in BL) then it can't be successfully used to read BIKE and HIKE. \n\nLet me know if u want a reference to her article."

full_text: @SarahGlaser9 @CherylCrocket11 Sarah, what you're referring to is Linnea Ehri's 4th (consolidated) stage of sight word learning. The key is fully decoding the word LIKE a few times. Then IKE becomes a sight "word" which can be used to decode BIKE and HIKE without letter-by-letter decoding.
full_text(utf-8): b'@SarahGlaser9 @CherylCrocket11 Sarah, what you\'re referring to is Linnea Ehri\'s 4th (consolidated) stage of sight word learning. The key is fully decoding the word LIKE a few times. Then IKE becomes a sight "word" which can be used to decode BIKE and HIKE without letter-by-letter decoding.'

Did you know that @ILAToday began as a We-Better-Circle-the-Wagons response to Rudolf Flesch's book "Why Johnny Can't Read" in 1955?

For more on the history of reading instruction see here:
https://t.co/CdbVSAyIzD

full_text:
Looks like @ILAToday has come out with a new "brief" on phonics - and they say a couple of worthwhile things. They specifically endorse both blending and decodable text. That's something!
https://t.co/HivzsOx9qu
full_text(utf-8): b'Looks like @ILAToday has come out with a new "brief" on phonics - and they say a couple of worthwhile things. They specifically endorse both blending and decodable text. That\'s something!\nhttps://t.co/HivzsOx9qu'

full_text: @ehanford @ILAToday Unfortunately, the ILA statement then becomes incoherent. Referring to blending, decodable text, and phonemic awareness, the ILA states "the hard work of teaching phonics begins AFTER these characteristics are in place." What does that even mean?
full_text(utf-8): b'@ehanford @ILAToday Unfortunately, the ILA statement then becomes incoherent. Referring to blending, decodable text, and phonemic awareness, the ILA states "the hard work of teaching phonics begins AFTER these characteristics are in place." What does that even mean?'

full_text:
@ehanford @ILAToday It also states that decodable text is "essential for building a faster foundation in early reading." 

Blending and decodable text. That does represent some progress for the ILA.
full_text(utf-8): b'@ehanford @ILAToday It also states that decodable text is "essential for building a faster foundation in early reading." \n\nBlending and decodable text. That does represent some progress for the ILA.'

full_text: @ehanford @ILAToday The call for explicit, systematic phonics is 20 years behind the National Reading Panel's identical call. Yet I think @ILAToday does make some progress in this paper. Specifically it calls for blending to be "frequently modeled and applied."
full_text(utf-8): b'@ehanford @ILAToday The call for explicit, systematic phonics is 20 years behind the National Reading Panel\'s identical call. Yet I think @ILAToday does make some progress in this paper. Specifically it calls for blending to be "frequently modeled and applied."'

full_text: @MrsBCteach @kamaria1001 On the other end of the spectrum, the few students who are having trouble with a concept- even when it is explicitly taught (as synthetic phonics always does) - will need extra attention - perhaps from a teacher's aide. This is a concern no matter what the method.
full_text(utf-8): b"@MrsBCteach @kamaria1001 On the other end of the spectrum, the few students who are having trouble with a concept- even when it is explicitly taught (as synthetic phonics always does) - will need extra attention - perhaps from a teacher's aide. This is a concern no matter what the method."

full_text: @MrsBCteach @kamaria1001 The one or two students who are "reading fluently" will also benefit by what I suggested to Kamaria - especially hearing stories read and then discussing those stories.

full_text: Also, the one on the right (from Heinemann) is basically a Whole Language book. The one on the left is a Synthetic Phonics book.

full_text: @kamaria1001 Kamaria, if you're teaching a group of beginners, where is it written that there must be a time set aside for small group reading instruction? Teach decoding to the entire class for half the period - and read quality literature TO them (with discussion) the other half.
